posts.message:
Top Internet and Browser vendors are working on a draft for HTTP2: a new version of the protocol at the foundation of the Internet.
Daniel Stenberg (author and maintainer of cURL, who works for Mozilla) shares some of the details about the process and current state of draft.
Things I learned:
- HTTP2 will be binary, not text based.
- HTTP2 started with Google's SPDY protocol.
- You can enable HTTP2 today if you're using Firefox (I turned it on in Nightly). I think Twitter already supports HTTP2 (but I'm not sure).
- So far, HTTP2 will allow for non-SSL connection. There's a push to make SSL/TLS required for all connection (which I'm in a favor of, I have to say).
- Main goal seems to be to reduce number of trips between server and client.
He put together a PDF with all the details. Check it out. It's not all technical details but also history of HTTP and how we got here.
http://daniel.haxx.se/http2/

posts.message: I have a thought that I wanted to share with you guys. Does it make sense to build a recurring subscription for businesses in MENA? Something like Recurly and Chargify? From our experience people like Payfort don't give you this stuff out of the box.

posts.message:
In JavaScript or jQuery you often need to find out which key was pressed. Unfortunately, we don’t have it as easy as comparing it against a string like “esc” or “space bar”.
Each key on the keyboard is associated with a number, or what we call a keyCode and it is accessed on the event object.

posts.message:
Sending & receiving emails is a pain in the neck. Mandrill is trying to solve this problem. It's very fast. The free quota is 12K/month, which is enough when you're starting. It's by MailChimp, so they know what they are doing.

Notable competing services are SendGrid & Postmark.
posts.caption: mandrill.com
posts.description: Mandrill is a new way for apps to send transactional email. It runs on the delivery infrastructure that powers MailChimp.
